It is unsafe on so many levels working here.

Do yourself a favour and listen to what people say about this place, avoid.....you can do much better!

review_title: Great people, great young people but lack of structure
pros: - most of my colleagues were awesome, good work environment, really understanding managers, flexible working

pros:
Genuinely a lovely bunch of people to work with day to day. friendly and really care about raising money to support young people. 
Annual leave, 30 days plus 3 free days at Christmas
cons:
Currently in the middle of the third restructure and third CEO within the last 5 years. 
Senior leadership say all the right things about empowering staff and protecting mental health but ultimately throw their weight around and push teams to their breaking point.
Really hierarchical and do not value the skills and experience of their staff resulting in high turnover. 
There has been a pay review going on for about the last 5 years, no need to worry though, it’s scheduled for ‘Autumn’.

review_title: Good for an entry-level position or change of sector
job_title: Youth Development Lead in Edinburgh, Scotland
pros: Great working with young people, schools and partners
cons: Very corporate, low pay, bogged down in process, hard to advance unless in one of the big centres

job_title: Senior Performance Analyst in London, England
pros: Lower management and ground level staff are the only reason the organisation is still functioning.
cons:
Poor pay.
Over worked. 
Undervalued. 
Upper and senior management detached from the ground level resulting in decisions being made that only add to the work and feeling of being undervalued that staff encounter daily. 
The organisation as a whole has lost its way and focuses more on the numbers. All that seems to matter are how many clients are helped, which is then used to increase funding - the results of which are then spent on technology and processes that aren't naturally aligned to the organisations business model, which then results in the oversights and extra work needed to plug the gaps of these oversights falling to a work force that is, already, underpaid within the sector and arguably undervalued - being given more work and responsibility for the same poor pay.

Add to this the problems caused by the pandemic and it compounding of the issues mentioned above the current state of morale is lower than its ever been and it doesn't look to be improving any time soon.

pros: Great programmes for Young People
cons: Work politics and not amazing salary

pros: The best people I've worked for or with
cons: There aren't any bad points

pros:
The best thing about working at the Trust is the people - colleagues, the young people and the volunteers. They make the job fun and feel like a big family. Caring managers who encourage staff to develop both professionally and personally. 

The support and focus on wellbeing during the pandemic has been far, far stronger than any of my friends and family's employers. Wellbeing hours, numerous activities and opportunities to connect with colleagues. 

New CEO is doing a great job in my opinion - communicating clearly to staff during the pandemic. 

There are many opportunities every week to take on responsibilities and do creative projects. 

It is a really fun place to work in my opinion. 

Great work life balance, very flexible and understanding management.
cons:
Salary is below market average. I worry about bills some months. My salary is not much higher than the living wage and I am highly qualified.

Not many promotion opportunities. There are some but competition is fierce.

IT equipment is old and slow.

review_title: Transformative and supportive place to work
pros: The people are extremely dedicated, friendly and committed to the work they do, making it a very inspirational and motivational place to work. You are also entrusted to use your initiative, proactivness and take responsibility from an early stage. Coupled with this everyone wants to help each other as well as young people helping you to feel confident to run with ideas and continually improve. There is a great work ethic as well as work life balance and flexibility.
cons: Our IT team is great but often very stretched, meaning developments and improvements can take time. Perhaps slightly more pressure and and accountability could lead to even higher performance.

review_title: Positive work environment and amazing colleagues
pros: The Trust truly cares for its staff and young people. I found management at both middle and executive level to be welcoming and approachable.  Personal development is encouraged and supported whilst feedback is regular and constructive. The Trust makes a huge difference to many lives and the true reward of this job is seeing the impact on young people.
cons: Large workload and salary in the lower range for this type of role.

review_title: Fantastic induction into an inspiring organisation!
job_title: Head Of Operations in Luton, East of England, England
pros: Every part of my onboarding experience has been fantastic - the interview was really swiftly organised and I was regularly communicated with throughout. My induction has been really well organised and everyone I’ve worked with so far is incredible helpful, efficient and passionate about providing an excellent experience for every young person we support. I already know this is a fantastic organisation to be part of - great regular links to the cause. review_title: The people are amazing. The rest is just frustrating
pros:
The people
The cause
Making a difference
cons: The left hand doesn’t know what the right hand is doing - so frustrating.

review_title: Rewarding and inspirational place to work
job_title: Head of Partnerships (South) in London, England
pros:
I joined the Prince's Trust 5 months ago and it's been to date by far the best career move I have ever made. Some of the pros include:

The People - everyone I've worked with to date has been welcoming, supportive and inspired to help the Young People we work with at the Trust. Starting a new job and having an induction whilst working from home could have been challenging but from day one, I've been made to feel welcome and supported.

The work we do - everyone who works at the Trust takes pride in what they do and this makes the job an inspiring and rewarding one - you are helping to shape a Young Person's future and make a difference to someone's life and as such, makes coming to work and working hard so much easier.

Work / Life balance - this is taken very seriously by the company - from a really generous holiday allowance (30 days + christmas shutdown), wellness hours to acknowledge the extra hours people are putting in whilst wfh through to the 'Perk Up' benefits, you can tell the organisation puts it's employees wellbeing first and wants to ensure you feel supported and valued.
cons:
Salary - the slary isn't great, but then that's the charity sector and having worked for large tech companies that pay well and offer free lunches, I would rather trade that in, get the lower salary and know what I am doing is helping people who need help at this time. They also get this which is why when they can, like holiday allowances and added benefits, like Perk Up, they try to make up for it.

IT - it needs to be dealt with at a senior level - the IT team needs more resources to make it efficient and the software needs upgrading now everyone is working from home.

pros: Cause, Purpose, Culture, Ambition, Impact, Colleagues
cons: Lower end of pay scale

pros: The frontline staff are incredible! So down to earth and with a genuine passion for helping young people. Teams become groups of friends so quickly and easily without losing the professionalism needed to get the job done. I've worked at some really corporate places where every conversation just feels so fake and forced and The Prince's Trust is nothing like that.
cons: It's also a very different experience for non frontline staff e.g. fundraising, marketing, I haven't had a lot of exposure to those teams but from what I've heard it can be just like the corporate companies that I mentioned in the pros. Also salary - I work with some incredibly hardworking and talented people who are 100% not being paid enough.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Manchester City Centre, England
pros:
Used to be a great place to work, with job satisfaction. 

Enjoyed the best part of it, but went down hill quickly 

Some great colleagues on the ground working with young people. 

Only a couple of the good managers left.
cons:
Poor atmosphere, with no senior leadership acknowledgement to staff below himself. Deputy director has a backbone of a jelly fish, no clear direction. 

Exco know how to dodge a question, with no clear answers or guidance. 

No salary or career progression. 

Way below industry standards on pay

pros: friendly atmosphere, supportive network of colleagues, rewarding work, making a difference in lives of young people, leading youth charity in UK
cons: pay is low but this is the same across all charity sector

pros: Working with young people. Recognises transferable skills. Some great knowledgeable people although many leave/have left.
cons:
Long hours, very poor pay. Other paid disproportionately higher for less expertise and experience as there is a lack of recognition for work and technical expertise. You need to be a line manager to move up yet many are not good line managers. Very hierarchical and top heavy. People working directly with the young people or delivery partners do most of the work that the trust stands for and require experience to do this well but are paid the lowest. Executives ("low level" role) are brilliant and have incredible knowledge of what young people need and build rapport and trust with them, often not easy, yet this isn't recognised (hence lower level). Staff skills not fully utilised nor recognised. It's great they hire people with transferable skills but it also means people with little experience or technical  knowledge join the trust at high positions. This means knowledge and experience from the sector isn't there and leads to the trust not moving with the times and other youth organisations doing a better job learning from their mistakes and previous experience. The trust likes numbers not qualitative feedback (unless it's a positive quote).
 Leadership promotes their own peer group and gives themselves promotions. Much of the leadership team has little experience outside of the trust let alone the sector and does not involve staff in decision making, all of which leads to a disconnect from the young people we are supposed to serve.

pros: Feel good mission, Prince Charles's magnificent vision

review_title: Great cause but take advantage of their staff
pros:
The cause - able to make a difference and to have the opportunity to see the difference you make regularly 
Colleagues
Holiday entitlement 
Easily able to work from home
cons:
They expect so much of their staff - so much pressure - given extra responsibilities regularly but never rewarded for it.
I have worked for many charities and this is by far the worse in terms of pay. I saw the very large pay band when I joined the trust and thought I could easily work my way up through the band - but after 4 years I haven’t been able to. I have seen new staff join my team and have been started on the same salary that I’m on currently. 
Loyalty and hard work doesn’t get you anywhere here. 
Only way to earn more is to get a promotion, but they have to appreciate that not everyone wants to be a Manager.
I have been given extra responsibilities, but never been rewarded for doing them. 
They rely on staff doing a lot of overtime to get the work done.

pros:
The people that work here are so friendly.  Always willing to lend a hand and going above and beyond to assist colleagues.  On top of this, the social scene outside of work is fantastic, with plenty of clubs and groups to be a part of.  They have even adopted my partner into a few groups.
This has to be the most flexible organisation I've ever worked for.  I work from home often and honestly get to choose my own hours.  The workforce is really agile and my remote team still stays close-knit due to the great technology we have access to.
There are plenty of opportunities for development that I have taken advantage of so far and I've seen multiple colleagues progress upwards or sideways into new and exciting projects as well.
30 days holiday each year and having the time between Christmas and New Years off is nothing to turn your nose up at either.
cons:
Although there are regular morning teas and lunchroom meetings; I would love to have some free cereal, toast, and fruit available for everyone in the morning.
The people who work in IT are wonderful, but it can be a little difficult for technical problems to be rectified in a timely manner across such a huge dispersed workforce.

pros: Good as listening to people

pros: There is a real camaraderie amongst frontline staff, people really want to support young people.
cons:
The Trust used to be an incredible place to work, but has lost its way in the past 2/3 years. 
- Leadership is almost nonexistent. Regional management are so removed from delivery and don’t know how to support staff. Many are more focussed on their reputation and career progression and this comes at the detriment of real support for young people. 
- All too often senior managers are reported to have made discriminatory comments, particularly about women and parents in the workplace. Complaints are brushed under the carpet. Too many have lost any sense of organisational values.
- National leadership’s focus has shifted too far into achieving ‘the numbers’ at all costs. This means quality has dipped significantly, and staff are encouraged to support young people significantly better off than the real target group to manipulate outcomes.
- Money wasted on vanity projects like a database that isn’t fit for purpose and swings in offices rather than being directed to those who need it.

pros:
"some" young people get supported into training or employment
Many grassroots staff are dedicated to helping young people
cons: An organization wide restructure has led to chaos within the trust. All operations staff now doing several jobs at once. No clear direction. No idea on how it is even possible to do a job that 4 people once did. Massive investment in a computer system which is archaic, doesn't work and is impossible to use. Focus now on doing less than ever with young people yet claiming to do more. The purpose? To have a PR exercise in a couple of years claiming to have reached millions of young people. The reality us that it is quantity over quality. Staff stressed yet afraid to say so as this is frowned upon.  Young people are simply numbers to this organization as are the staff.

review_title: Great organisation doing very valuable work with young people
pros: There are opportunities to engage, contribute and be involved at all levels of the organisation. There are means of getting one's voice heard through a number of channels and contributing to team plans and the direction of travel. Compared with other charities in the sector working hours and holidays are reasonable and there are perks to compensate for less than competitive wages. The charity is absolutely passionate about young people and making a difference in their lives. It employs a young, enthusiastic workforce with high expectations and a dedicated work ethic.
cons: There is an expectation of delivering 'more' with 'less'. However this is not uncommon across the charitable sector and the Prince's Trust is no better or worse in this respect than other organisations in the current financial climate. The Head Office / national function needs further clarity.

review_title: Every day I get to Start Something positive to help more young people
job_title: Corporate Partnerships Manager in London, England
pros: It's such a positive experience being part of The Prince's Trust community and getting to work here every day! I've worked here for the past 5 years and every day is packed full of projects, initiatives and campaigns to get stuck into and support more young people. Very proud to be part of such a special fundraising team. We are so lucky to work with so many brands and partners who are passionate about supporting young people. Working here and being supported by a great team - means we can turn the power of these partnerships into great results for young people and raise vital funds. Every day is a great experience, full of colleagues and volunteers who are united by our vision to help the next one million young people. Looking forward to many more happy years to come!
cons: I can't see any - Prince's Trust is a very special place to work

pros: In essence the support to young people is good. Colleagues supportive as we all try to muddle through the chaos ( which is more than can be said for Management)
cons: Management haven't a clue, absolute chaos.  The restructure last year was completely messed up, new CEO announced to all Volunteers it was happening whilst it was still in confidential consultation stage.   Staff had to chase up HR 4 months after funding out to find out what was actually happening. The restructure was meant to streamline programs, they lost so many good long term staff and are now struggling to cope. Can't see this mess of an organisation lasting much longer.  Sad as it's the young people who will suffer. Pen pushers who are only interested in targets which is far from what Prince's Trust is mean to be. Most at senior level wouldn't have a clue how to talk to an actual young person.

review_title: Unique and passionate place to work but room for improvement
pros:
*Passion to make a difference and support young people
*Very ambitious and driven fundraising team
*Large organisation with opportunities to progress or move sideways
*Some very talented individuals including in leadership
*Exposure to lots of corporates and c-suite leaders in fundraising
*Great annual leave benefits
cons:
*Pay is below market rate, more opportunity if you're external hire then internal to progress through scales
*Lack of consistency of line management quality, and some unsupportive cultures are accepted
*Quite cororporate and stressful at times for a charity
*Lots of restructures and upheaval at times, change takes time to take effect and see results

review_title: Great cause, worthwhile work, bean counting, elitist senior management team.
job_title: National Project Manager in Leicester, England
pros: The direct work with young people & a fantastic cause. Having spent 12 years with the organisation I have seen the support it has given disadvantaged young people. I have also seen the support and dedication that all staff brings to the to their role.
cons: I write this 6 months after I left to allow some reflection. PT has made some significant missteps in my opinion .... a focus on numbers of young people rather than those most in need (mission creep), internal projects that costs a lot but weren't managed properly and lack of clarity around organisation direction.

pros:
Great colleagues, great aims and goals, good office location

Everyone is enthusiastic and driven to help young people.
cons:
Senior management leadership not great, lots of restructures - every year!  Do they know what they are doing?

Values are made up of half of the performance review, however it is not felt that it is lived by senior management.

It seems that new people get more as the market has improved and its harder to get people in, filling a vacancy can take a long time.

It does not pay to be a long serving employee - don't waste your time on loyalty.

pros: When you get the opportunity to meet and speak to the young people and hear their stories then you really understand why charities like this are needed.
cons:
The care and support of the young people isn't the charity's biggest priority. It is all about numbers (i.e. supporting 'the most' young people / running 'the most' programmes in the UK) and doing anything possible just to get more money in the door - even if it's not what the young people actually need.

The turnover of fundraising staff is really high and it's quite sad how lots of ambitious and passionate people go to work there and get disillusioned pretty quickly.

review_title: Great work with young people but chaotic and poor performing senior leadership
pros: Working with young people is so rewarding.  Hearing life’s transform is amazing.
cons:
As many have said the restructure was brutal and not very well executed.  The organisation has blundered through a number of major change projects, spending millions on systems that do not work - literally.  

CEO shows complete stupidity when he called staff turds.  Unforgivable and should be hauled coals by Clarence House if not fired.

Increasingly hierarchical at the top level, even though some nice people.

I do not believe the Trust will fold but I do think it needs to sort itself out.  It’s a 40+ year charity that should be better than it is.

review_title: Fantastic colleagues and culture but low pay and hard to progress
pros:
Everyone is fully behind the cause - it is all about the young people! 
The culture is great - everyone is very friendly, helpful, open, hardworking and passionate 
Very good work life balance - can be 9-5 on the dot!
Some people stay at The Trust forever because they love it so much!
cons:
Can be difficult to progress which means quite a high turn over.
Low salary which means people often leave for bigger salaries elsewhere.
Social side can lack in many teams - the office can be quiet with a lot of people focusing on their work (perhaps too much) and there is not a lot of socialising outside of working hours which is a shame

pros: A safe prison. You could stay for years and those who thrive on bullying would be promoted higher and higher.
cons:
Where do I start? I don't usually do reviews, but I wanted to warn people who are lured in by working for a high profile charity that you would have more joy licking the pavements clean than working for this tyrannical organisation. Rules with an iron rod, and even leaving the organisation isn't easy. I've recently handed in my notice, after being told I am in 'need of improvement' (like I am a basement flat in a up and coming area), they gave me hassle over a leaving date. One minute they hate me, the next they love me, this is like an abusive relationship!

Be careful folks, these are not what they seem, they are ruthless. Their Health and Safety, wellbeing is shot, I don't know one person who loves it. It's sickening.

pros: Very rewarding role with regards to the young people you support. The position as an executive gives you exposure to work with many stakeholders, internal and external of the organisation. There is a significant level of responsibility placed on the exec, which is fantastic if you want to excel your career. However you are required to work in areas which are outside your comfort zone, which I think is great.
cons: As for any charity, your pay doesn't necessarily reflect your work load. However like many that work for PT, you work there because you are passionate about working and supporting their clients and young people. Salary is important, but there are other jobs if this is your main concern.

pros:
Workmates are lovely, dedicated and hard-working.
It's fantastic to see young people being helped.
cons:
The CEO referred to staff as turds in a swimming pool in a video posted on the intranet.
Senior management (mostly old white men) seem to have no strategic experience whatsoever and the organisation lurches from one restructure to another with little regard for how mass redundancies and low pay affects morale.
Huge amounts of money spent on IT systems, but there's never any hot water in the staff toilets, which are disgusting.

review_title: Poor management that have forgotten why the Trust exists
pros: The young people we support are amazing
cons:
The Trust was set up by Prince Charles to support disadvantaged young people.  Although we constantly repeat this mission in all external communications, the reality is that management have lost sight of this.

The Trust is now entirely focused on driving ever-increasing numbers of young people, attracting public and corporate funders and developing the PT brand for the benefit of management, partners and trustees.

The staff are over-worked, underpaid and, as a result, the quality of support they can offer young people has become a minor consideration.

review_title: Fantastic workplace - below average on salaries
pros:
- Lovely workplace atmosphere
- Career progression is taken seriously. There are often options to try on new hats internally or go on secondment
- There are lots of social activities for staff
- Innovation is taken seriously and staff at all levels are given the opportunity to pitch ideas
- Fundraising staff are very intelligent and switched on
- Frontline staff are incredibly inspiring and knowledgable
- There have been public conversations about how the organisation can be supporting families more
cons:
- Salary is low compared to other major charities
- Maternity pay is the legal minimum
- Public opinion and understanding of the charity is quite poor which can affect how impactful staff can be

review_title: An absolute joke of a charity!
pros: Working with young people, wonderful volunteers and partners
cons: Restructure of the charity in June 2018 was a complete abomination of a disaster! Anyone with a shred of skill, personality or ambition either left or were made redundant! It was like a mass scale massacre! That along with a defunct oracle system, lack of genuine empathy for staff from senior management and awful pay that would take forever to climb to the top of your payscale! I don’t even believe that senior staff and the CEO Nick Stace actually care about the young people they are trying to help or they would never have changed a system that now no longer supports young people in all areas!

review_title: Meaningful and impactful organisation but poor structure and management
pros:
Transform the lives of young people with amazing stories of overcoming setbacks and challenging situations
Great staff collaboration and support at local level
Flexibility in role to choose areas of focus - delivery, outreach, partnerships
cons:
Lack of clear decison-making and management 
Disconnect between actual delivery and meeting funding requirements
Heavy workload and no formal training in place to offload capacity to new starters
Lack of diversity as you progress in the organisation. 
The more friends you make and drinks you go for, the more opportunities will be offered to you rather than being recognised and rewarded for your work ethic and getting the job done.

pros: The people are amazing, dedicated and hard working. The young people inspiring and amazing me every day and are the only reason I'm still there.
cons: Far too top heavy, complete disregard for the opinions of front line staff and lack of clear and honest communication from above. Too many restructures and no recognition of unions - Trust Exchange is not the same as a union!

pros:
Great team and able to work directly with young people - none of the formal rules and regulations you get in the public sector

My manager cares about my development and there are plenty of opportunities to grow here.
cons: Can't think of any - The Prince's Trust is a very fair employer - if you work hard, so some passion and have the right attitude you'll love it. If you want to follow the same process every day and have a set list of tasks then look somewhere else!

review_title: I learned news skills and developed myself ( by myself).
pros: I really enjoyed helping young people.
cons: Manager.  Had no people skills whatsoever.  Offended most people and believed she could speak to me in any way she wanted.  Even set me up for a disciplinary which was not of my doing but as she had brought someone from HR in London for the day to 'give it', there was no way out of it as Managers support Managers whether they are right or wrong.

pros:
Awesome colleagues and managers, everyone is friendly and passionate about the cause. 
Very rewarding work with young people. 
9-5 work hours (technically)
cons:
Underpaid and no progression opportunities. 
Often do overtime due to workload but not paid. 
Working for a big machine means very little room for change and innovation. 
No creativity, everything is stifled because the charity is too big. 
Huge staff turnover. Programme Execs tend to stay a year on average then leave.

job_title: Deputy Team Leader in London, England
pros:
Great ethos & reputation resulting in lots of support for your work
Helping young people grow in confidence & individuality.
Solid Mon-Fri role with paid holiday.
cons: The money is awful. Really.

pros: Simply an environment that welcomes everyone and where everyone is willing to help.  It's an environment that is forever learning and does not stand still.  This may frustrate some people as it can involve restructures or working differently, but the willingness to progress and deliver more for young people is clearly at the heart of every decision. The executive team tell you at induction that you can approach them with any suggestions, questions and comments and they stand by this. In fact, today I was in a meeting where I saw a team member make a suggestion and immediately it was acted on because that team member needed this support. You are not just listened to, but you are heard here and it makes for a valued working environment.  The organisation works strategically on a national level, but delivers and engages with Young people and supporters locally. This presents some very local and meaningful conversations that really does have an impact. More of this can mean more impact.
cons: It's a massive organisation and with this comes the complexities of knowing what departments exist and who  exists and does what.  You really have to be willing to ask questions and get out there and find answers. This can be a great way to get to know the organisation, but it comes with the frustrations of  finding out what you need to learn , finding the answer quickly enough and everyone in the organisation having a similar knowledge on the same subject matter. In fact , when you start this can be very challenging and worrying . Alongside this, it is a lean organisation (great as the funding goes to young people first) but a great deal of the systems are very archaic and add to the day to day admin and can take you away from your main focus.  So many staff work regionally, but communication is not regionally aligned and it proves difficult to engage Young people and externals without the regional messaging and measurements. There is so much impact happening up and down the country, but it is not articulated, communicated and celebrated locally. This can make the organisation appear like it has nothing to say or offer locally when we are in those communities.

pros: The company attracts high quality employees and I have had the pleasure of working with some amazing colleagues
cons: Local management is poor, there is lack of direction and a feel that no one really knows what they are doing. A lack of communication and support from senior management contributes to this. Due to the extremely rapid staff turnover teams are rarely filled to capacity which increases the workload and adds to the lack of direction as knowledge is lost as colleagues leave, and managers have not taken the time to understand the roles of their team to train new staff. There are zero opportunities for progression, both in terms of promotion and pay. There is a pay bracket in place but management admit there is no structure to move up this bracket, and colleagues who have been in post for years have seen little pay increase, which is hugely disproportionate to the work they have been doing. Finally I have huge concerns about the priorities of the Princes Trust, there is a huge focus on reporting high numbers of course participants and not on the quality of work being done. I have not enjoyed seeing deceptive marketing materials encouraging participants to this service, selling much more than the Trust has on offer. Employees generally feel over worked and under paid/valued and this explains the turnover in staff

review_title: The young people are life changing, but the management prevents you from making a real difference in their lives.
job_title: Outreach and Development in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: The young people you work with are amazing, and it's great to see them develop. I really enjoyed working with some of the staff too, they were very talented and had a real passion for helping people. Some of the programmes provide fantastic opportunities and the options are flexible to suit young people's needs. The values of the trust are fantastic.
cons: Lack of opportunity for training and further development of staff, especially staff working directly with young people. The most hard to reach young people are sometimes forgotten, as there is too much focus on getting "success stories" out there, there is less acknowledgement of what the average young person experiences. HR are very disorganized, I have known staff that were awarded a higher grade after an interview process, then they were told that they would not get to act in the higher grade because of a pay freeze. Too much focus on getting famous people to be seen to support the trust, than actually spending time with young people, very few of the staff actually have any direct contact with young people, whilst outsourcing is a fantastic way to diversify skills and programmes offered, it means that the organisation loses sight of their client group. When attending a meeting for all staff in the area, the question was asked "who is our client?" Everyone from fundraisers to patrons to schools were mentioned, but young people were not mentioned once. Staff that directly work with young people are the least valued in the company, both in rate of pay and their opinions.

pros:
Lovely people - almost everyone is friendly, supportive and good at their jobs 
Good opportunities for career progression (especially at head office) 
Lots of interesting projects to work on
Mix of exciting events and projects with the feeling that you're doing something worthwhile
Good annual leave, plus you usually get a week off at Christmas
cons:
Sometimes it can be a bit hierachical 
Could be a bit more forward-thinking on things like flexible working, staff social media use, maternity policy

job_title: Team Assistant in Rushden, East Midlands, England
pros: Learn new skills;learn about how different people are and live. Make new friends and experience new things. Helps you think about your future and past in my experience.
cons: Can have people treating you wrong but the people around you can support you and give back-up.

review_title: If you're as lucky as I was, you'll have an AMAZING time
job_title: Digital Marketing Manager in London, England
pros:
1. Start on 25 days annual leave and gain 1 extra day per year of employment up to an extra 5 days - so if you work there 5 years you'd get 30 days holiday, plus 8 bank holidays, plus the days off between Christmas and New Year for free
2. Maternity leave policy is good - they've introduced a policy which means you don't have to pay it back if you don't return to work
3. Cool projects & events - access to work on events such as The Prince's Trust Awards, Palace to Palace cycle ride & more
4. Autonomy over your projects - middle-to-upper management trust you to run with campaigns and projects
5. Opportunity to try new things 
6. Unpaid 6 month sabbatical after 5 years of employment - optional
7. Depending on the team you're in, you may get to go to cool events like Prince's Trust Awards - a special red carpet event with celebrities
8. Great work life balance - flexi hours (8-4 9-5 10-6) and work from home option
9. Really cool youthful new centres to work from e.g. Birmingham, Newcastle, Poplar
10. Friendly staff culture
11. Management trusts you to work remotely, work flexible hours, and to own your work

I went from Coordinator to Manager in three years, there's scope for career progression if you show willing, enthusiasm, determination and initiative. I'd recommend working there, from the experience *I* have had, but I am also unhappy with the way my line report was treated. There's A LOT of change at the mo, I'm sure things will improve in 12 months, but right now it's not good for some staff.
cons: Some staff will have fantastic experiences and move up the career ladder. I was given so many opportunities and I couldn't be more grateful for that. The organisation needs to get rid of short term contracts, it's really not good for staff members health.

review_title: Organisation has some great aims, poor execution.
pros: The young people the organisation help. The front line delivery staff who are passionate about helping disadvantaged young people.
cons: Directors and management. The organisation is too hierarchical, too many mangers who can't make a decision unless 10 people above agree. Frequent restructures that leave staff unhappy and ultra defensive HR department that never can see error in it's process. Staff who don't fit in are paid off.

pros:
- good training opportunities
-surrounded by excellent and interesting colleagues
-get to work to make a difference to other's lives
-good pay for charity sector
-FUN
cons:
-hard work and large caseload
-Some decision makers have no experience of what it's actually like on the ground, causing a conflict of interest for young people 
-Sometimes the core values are forgotten in some parts of the organisation

review_title: Rewarding job but need to fix the systems/paperwork
job_title: Operations Executive in Belfast, Northern Ireland
pros: We really are helping young people move forward. Very rewarding. The local NI team are really supportive. Everyone is now encouraged to test new approaches/initiatives. Lots of well-being support & extra social activities. People look out for each other. Countries now have more freedom.
cons: The systems don’t work causing everyone frustrations. Far too much reliance of funders who need us to spend more time on paperwork than helping young people.

review_title: Lost the main focus of why it exists
pros: Working with the young people. They are inspiring and impressive
cons: Management are too focused on corporate partnerships and celebrity connections. Too many decisions made that are not in the interest of the young people we are supposed to support. Poor organisation, poor use of resources and poor evaluation of outcomes

pros:
Some very talented colleagues.
PT supports the Young People who need it most.
Some great programmes.
cons:
The unfair pay structure is a long standing issue for many staff.
The workload is often unmanageable.
Senior management appear out of touch with their staff and the reality of client facing work.

pros: Worked with great people who cared about young people
cons:
Less Focus on Young People 
More focus on bums on seats
Experience has been stripped from the company
Company values are no longer considered 
Poor treatment of grass roots staff

job_title: Assistant Team Leader in Enniskillen, Northern Ireland
pros: I enjoyed working with young adults and helping them develop skills. There is a lot of fun tasks and hands on involvement. I had a fantastic colleague to work alongside which makes a huge difference when you are trying to control the classroom.
cons: There was not a lot of progression where I was. The support could have better. The students can be difficult to work with and I did not receive my formal training in the correct manner to deal with these situations.

review_title: Brilliant people..... shame about how it’s run
pros:
Amazing employees who genuinely care about young people

Birmingham centre is amazing 

Decent benefits 

Inclusive environment
cons:
Organised chaos 

To many restructures 

Low esteem among employees due to restructures 

Loss of knowledge due to restuctures.... just look at the HR team for example

review_title: Not the worst place to work but very clicky.
pros: The people are essentially good. The work the charity does is brilliant.
cons: staff are not as valued as much as they were in the past. Moral was at an all time low across the board, when I left.

pros:
Most of the frontline staff are very well intentioned.
Annual leave policy very good
Job satisfaction can be good- seeing young people move in to outcomes is amazing
cons: In last six years there have been three major restructures. Staff have been made redundant whilst there are vacant posts. No encouragement or support to retain people. Management differs vastly and it’s pit luck on who you get and what they decide. They don’t seem to value middle managers and frontline delivery staff. Invested millions in an online system that is under utilised and not for for purpose. The new CEO referred to staff as turds.

job_title: Corporate Partnerships Manager in London, England
pros: Working alongside other talented and passionate colleagues, agile working, access to programmes and young people so you can really understand what the organisation does and to keep the cause close.
cons: The pay is lower than average for the same role in another charity. Though there has been a pay review carried out recently.

review_title: Disappointing start to what have been an exciting new strategy :(
pros:
Despite having an excellent experience, feeling valued, well supported with plenty of development opportunities and feeling like I was making a genuine impact on the lives of young people.............It all changed with the introduction of a new director and the announcement of a full operational restructure.

Outcomes for the young people are brilliant because of amazing and committed front line staff and delivery partners
cons:
There is now a toxic environment of fear and anxiety and a real lack of leadership.

I personally started the consultation period back in June and 3 months later I am still waiting to here if i have a job or not. During this time i have seen my friends, colleagues and the best staff  and management either leave, take redundancy or more shockingly be made redundant!

I fear the Trust no longer has the staff left or the experience to deliver our current work load and have so far not shown staff any form of transition plan, adding to the anxiety. everyone I have spoke to is experiencing low mood and morale.
The Trust have not been true to their own values throughout this process and have even been referred to as turds in a swimming pool by the CEO. Little does he know that his best people have just been flushed out to sea.

I have seen first hand metal health concerns being brushed aside. Staff need to be looked after and valued otherwise you'll have no staff to deliver programmes for young people and those who are left will be burdened with the additional strain.

review_title: Sad to see changes after 4 great years
pros: Working with the young people is amazing! There are some absolutely fantastic people all working to help vulnerable young people tale their next steps.
cons: Changes coming in are more focused on numbers accessing the services rather than programme quality. I feel mass redundancies are in their way.

pros: Enjoyed working with my colleagues, if it of hadn't been for them I would have been off work with stress
cons: No support from management!!! brought a whole new team in, gave them very little support and then 8 months later made them all redundant when other people were getting promotions without following a proper process.

pros:
Making a difference to young people who might not otherwise be given the chance.
Rewarding and satisfying to see the impact that the work can have on a young person's life.
cons:
Too many managers talk the talk only.
Management focus on statistics more than anything.
Bullying culture in some centres - management permitted!
Salary low for the sector.

review_title: An organisation I once believed in, now without direction and vision
job_title: Programmer Executive in Salford, North West England, England
pros: The organisation was once very committed to putting the young people at the centre of decision making, and had an experienced staff team that were committed to quality provision.
cons:
Lack of quality staff training and progression, this was raised by numerous individuals and was never actioned.  This compounded staffs frustrations therefore limiting the types of support and provision that could be offered safely.
Outdated recording systems despite paying considerable monies, this has resulted in duplication of work and confusion which is not conducive with accurate recording especially with reference to health and safety and safeguarding.
The organisation is consumed with hitting a target figure of young people which has led to a quantity focused outlook instead of quality.
Senior management team including the CEO which seem to have nothing but contempt towards grass root staff going so far as to refer to staff as "Turds".  As you can imagine this has not had a favourable response and again staff have felt undervalued and insulted.
The staff team following yet another restructure (The princes Trust does seem to have restructures every couple of years) have no clarity of job role as there used to be specialisms within the organisation that have now been reduced to general roles covering multiple programmes.  The job descriptions offer no clarity on the role being applied for which seems to have led to inexperienced staff being recruited and once in post they are uncertain of the expectations on them.  Most established staff are disillusioned to say the least and many are seeking alternate employment.
As an organisation it prides itself on the values
PASSIONATE
APPROACHABLE
INSPIRING
NON JUDGEMENTAL
EMPOWERING
All of these are an excellent way to treat the client group and staff team, the staff certainly apply these to the young people they work with however the organisation has weaponised these values and use them against staff if they speak out and share their views.

review_title: A once great place to work is nosediving into decline
pros: Staff below senior management level will work tirelessly and go above and beyond. They are - in all honesty - the only reason the Trust hasn't completely collapsed.
cons: Senior management and above don't see or won't see the enormous amount of effort their increasingly disenfranchised staff put in to ensure that the  strategic aims dreamt up by said - ridiculously distant and, quite frankly, uncaring - management. Progression and promotion are based on how well an individual is liked by management rather than their ability to do the job they are given. Exemplified by the last team to run the multi-million pound project which run over time, over spent, has caused major technological issue - which those left are having to deal with and fix after aforementioned project team ALL found new jobs. The business is constantly looking for the next big thing or trying to hop on the newest buzz - without addressing the issues caused by its last grand idea. On top of which is placed an absolute disgrace of a restructure. All this has resulted in a toxic environment, where very few are happy in their job (low wages aside), the top brass or not trusted, staff turnover in some areas is quite shocking - with long-term staff who have seen ALOT deciding that now is the time to leave, the head office resembles a ghost town and the staff that do choose to remain are asked/expected to work well beyond their capacity.  The last 5-6 years has basically been the iceberg that has all but sunk the ship. Anyone that says different is either afraid to admit the truth, a liar, very new or is senior management.

pros:
Colleagues are nice and within departments there is a good sense of community.
Options for flexible working
Does great work supporting young people and has a clear mission and values.
There are opportunities for volunteering on programmes if you do not have a role working directly with young people.
cons:
Low salaries 
Going through a big period of change and communication was lacking
Limited scope for progression/development

review_title: A sinking ship with no captain
pros:
Most of the staff are absolutely amazing and genuinely care about the work they do for young people. Passion and enthusiasm in buckets

Helping young people succeed is incredibly rewarding and the programmes themselves are robust and of good quality

Time off between Christmas and New Year in addition to your holiday allowance
cons:
1. The recent restructure is an absolute shambles - the new director has no empathy or interest in actually getting to know or support the teams as "there's no point when a lot of them are leaving anyway". No one knows how things are actually going to work - it's the blind leading the blind. Absolutely no leadership from any of the remaining senior management

2. A lot of fantastic staff were made redundant and higher positions given to staff who don't "live the values" and demonstrate the behaviors and attitudes we are all expected to.  ALL staff shocked by these decisions, they can't all be wrong??? There are now less than half the staff needed operationally - yet they got rid of people who had put in years of service. In the space of one week, we lost over 100 years worth of PT experience!!! Staff who have lost their jobs, then had no manager to support them as they were already redundant and had left. 

3. No consistency with support from managers - I've spoken to mine maybe 5 times over the last 2 years. Opportunities to progress have been blocked and there has been zero interest in supporting the team during tough times.

4. No real pay progression and maternity/paternity pay is bog standard

5. Constant restructures and other changes mean that we really can't identify what works and what doesn't

6. Too much focus on BRAND and not enough care of the people who actually make it all happen

7. Operations staff are grossly underpaid for the amount of responsibility and the workload they are given

pros: Some nice people in the company and easy to get along.
cons:
STAY AWAY from this charity. This charity only cares about young people. They don't care about their staff. It's all the talk. 

There is so much bullying in their London office, management are clueless and allow bullying in their charity. They preach 0% bullying policy but don't practice what they preach. It's all the talk. Senior managers are part of bullying and support the bully. They only care about themselves. Low pay, no progression opportunities, too much work, no respect, and support from managers.

pros: Freedom to make decisions. Lots of opportunities to work accords various functions. Most middle managers very good and offer excellent support to staff in front line positions.
cons: Can be hard to progress internally. Many staff are managed remotely and depending on the function it can be tricky to showcase your skills if you are wishing to progress

pros: The people you work with are the most helpful and inclusive group you will find. You feel you are a part of something that will help a large group of people achieve the inner greatness that they have.
cons: Communication between certain things is something that can be worked upon, as it can cause issues when it comes to planning in the long run

review_title: Incredible charity with great opportunities for employees
job_title: Senior Business Development Manager in London, England
pros: Amazing  opportunities to meet leaders in business, work with a remarkable team of fundraisers and witness first-hand the real impact on young people of the work of this incredible charity.
cons: Can be tough for new starters to get to grips on the multiple different processes and administration. As well as, getting a handle on everything the charity does.

review_title: Great place to get started in your career but little progression
pros: Supportive and fun environment with opportunity to help young people
cons: Management are out of touch and lack fresh leadership. Managers have been there for decades and fresh faces only stay a few years because of poor opportunities for growth. Slow to adapt to change.

review_title: Exceptionally unforgettable, most fantastic year of my life!
pros: Everyone is super friendly and always there if you need to talk. You get to work with people from all different walks of life and no 2 days are the same. Every day is unique and the young people I met have been so inspirational!
cons: You need to be prepared to go above and beyond!

pros: Great culture and a can do attitude.  I feel like I am making a real difference to the young people I am working with
cons:
As with most charities the pay is lower than the private sector..  

I accept we need a certain level of cash flow each but there is more to work than money

review_title: Ambitious Charity that constantly works hard to do it’s best for young people.
job_title: Operations Executive in Belfast, Northern Ireland
pros: Staff really passionate about helping young people, friendly environment, fun! good conditions of employment, flexi-time, new investment in staff development, helping to change lives makes it more than just a job, plenty of opportunities for progression throughout UK.
cons: Systems and processes need simplified.

pros: Interesting sphere of work - contact with some great young people with fantastic potential
cons: Chaotic and toxic environment. An organisation that knows it needs to move with the times or become irrelavent but has no idea how to do it. Expectations on lower grades are disproportionate to salaries on offer and prospects for progression poor. Externally maintains a strong reputation and protects it fiercely but internally is a maelstrom of confused thinking that threatens to sooner or later shatter that veneer.

pros: An amazing charity helping young people.
cons: A recent major restructure that has completely changed the whole ethos of this charity.   Lost a lot of valuable and experienced employees.

job_title: Assistant Team Leader in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros:
staff are amazing
management are helpful
everyone has a positive mentality towards students, 
everyone is willing to help when its needed
cons: it can be difficult to move forwards as a young staff member, students try to overpower younger staff members

pros: Great mission, inspiring and motivating concept.
cons: Terrible management, organisation and internal communication. No performance reviews or similar, no possibility for internal promotion and therefore no incentive for employees to work effectively. Volunteers are abused and put under pressure in the name of the mission, and no one cares to express gratitude whenthey actually go the extra mile.

pros: Committed and passionate colleagues
cons: Poor pay, very little room for progression. This is a huge charity with too many staff in certain departments and not enough in others.

review_title: Hard work is only valued by the young people not the management.
job_title: Operations Support Administrator in Poplar, England
pros: Working with young people is very rewarding.
cons: Hard work and positive results are seldom rewarded. Corners are cut with safeguarding.

pros: Absolutely love working here because of the people who I work alongside.
cons: Pay could be reviewed and increased

pros: Great Charity with people come in to work as you work with amazing people.
cons: Sometimes management will sideline you and only give you tasks when they want it and never vice versa.

pros: Fantastic co workers, lots of variation in work, young people always kept at the heart of decisions
cons: Sometimes we try to deliver too much at once.

pros: It was an amazing opportunity to be part of such an inspiring team.
cons: You have to attend some evening functions

review_title: Losing great people.  Change of CEO was dreadful. CEO referencing staff as turds was a new low!
pros: The impact for young people. Many people working there genuinely care.
cons: A change in CEO may have made sense, but he is full of spin and only seems to back stuff if it’s his idea. Have lost so many good people

job_title: Strategic Change Manager in London, England
pros: Nice people, reasonable working environments, good holiday entitlement.
cons: Low salaries, poor management, unrealistic expectations, financial pressure increasing, work/life balance at risk, very high attritition rates

pros: Staff nice, honest, hardworking, and frontline staff really do care about young people
cons: Management seem more interested in protecting the brand above all

pros: Amazing opportunities to work on huge events portfolio
cons: Busy team, often feel overworked.

pros: Great people and great mission led organisation
cons: None that I can think of

pros: Great colleagues, energetic and supportive environment
